items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely tonight, Monday 20th February 2023 into Tuesday 21st February 2023. High water is expected between 11pm and 1am. Water levels are expected to gradually rise and peak by 12 midnight on Monday 20th February 2023. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate. However, we are in a period of spring tides which peak after Wednesday and increase the risk of tide locking on the Broads system. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will issue further messages if the situation changes. We will update this message by 12 noon tomorrow, Tuesday 21st February 2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Dean, Singleton, Charlton, East Dean and Chilgrove
items.message: Very little rainfall has been recorded since 17 January 2023. At our indicator borehole at East Dean, groundwater is now one metre below the surface and falling nearly 10 centimetres each day. Very few impacts remain visible above ground, with only minimal amounts of water on roads. However, groundwater could continue to affect basements, and affect the ability of the sewage network to operate, potentially into March. Although the week ahead should remain predominantly dry, there is the chance of a small amount of rain around at times, with 5mm of rain currently forecast on Wednesday 22/02/2023 and the chance of some more unsettled weather through mid March. Details are very uncertain, and long term weather forecasting is difficult, but so long as we do not receive extremely wet weather, groundwater is expected to continue to fall through spring and summer. We will continue to monitor levels and forecasts. If you have pumps to help manage water levels in basements, please ensure they are operational. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely this evening, Monday 20th February 2023. High water is expected between 8pm and 11pm. Water levels are expected to gradually rise and peak by 10pm. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate. However, we are in a period of spring tides which peak after Wednesday and increase the risk of tide locking on the Broads system. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will issue further messages if the situation changes. We will update this message by 12 noon tomorrow, Tuesday 21st February 2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message: In Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle, groundwater levels are high but continue to very slowly fall following 4 weeks of dry weather. Since Friday 10/02/2023, the level at Finchdean has fallen by 15cm. Residual flooding impacts are expected to be affecting roads close to winterbourne streams and will continue to affect properties over the next few days. Over the next 5 days, only small amounts of rain are forecast, with up to 8mm on Thursday 16/02/2023. Groundwater levels in the valley are expected to continue falling throughout this period. Long range forecasting is difficult, but unsettled weather may return at the end of February or into March. If heavy rainfall affects the area, then groundwater levels could rise again. However, if dry weather continues to be forecast, we may remove this Flood Alert next week. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated or removed by 17:00 on Wednesday 22/02/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hambledon
items.message: In Hambledon, groundwater levels are high but continue to fall following 4 weeks of dry weather. Since Friday 10/02/2023, the level at Whitedale has fallen by 2.69m. Residual flood water may still be affecting cellars of properties on East Street and West Street. There is a very small amount of water in Fareham Road. Over the next 5 days, only small amounts of rain are forecast, with up to 8mm on Thursday 16/02/2023. Groundwater levels in Hambledon are expected to continue falling throughout this period. Long range forecasting is difficult, but unsettled weather may return at the end of February or into March. If heavy rainfall affects the area, then groundwater levels could rise again, and flooding impacts may return. However, if dry weather continues to be forecast, we may remove this Flood Alert next week. We continue to monitor the forecast. We advise that the community continues to remain prepared for flood impacts this winter. This Flood Alert will be updated or removed by 17:00 on Wednesday 22/02/2023.

items.description: Upper River Ems Valley
items.message: Very little rainfall has been recorded since 17 January 2023. At our indicator borehole in Compton, groundwater is still falling at 40 centimetres each day. Very few impacts remain visible above ground, with only minimal amounts of water on roads.  Although the week ahead should remain predominantly dry, there is the chance of a small amount of rain around at times, with 5mm of rain currently forecast on Wednesday 22/02/2023 and the chance of some more unsettled weather through mid March. Details are very uncertain, and long term weather forecasting is difficult, but so long as we do not receive extremely wet weather, groundwater is expected to continue to fall through spring and summer. We will continue to monitor levels and forecasts. If you have pumps to help manage water levels in basements, please ensure they are operational. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message: In Hursley, groundwater levels are high but continue to slowly fall following 4 weeks of dry weather. Since Tuesday 07/02/2023, the level at the Hursley borehole has fallen by 48cm. Cellars in the lower end of the village at South End Close and the Dolphin Inn pub may still be affected by residual flooding impacts. Over the next 5 days, only small amounts of rain are forecast, with up to 8mm on Thursday 16/02/2023. Groundwater levels in Hursley are expected to continue falling throughout this period. Long range forecasting is difficult, but unsettled weather may return at the end of February or into March. If heavy rain affects the area, then groundwater levels could rise again, and flooding impacts could return. However, if dry weather continues to be forecast, we may remove this Flood Alert next week. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated or removed by 17:00 on Wednesday 22/02/2023.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: This flood alert has been issued due to high tides and forecast weather conditions which may cause waves and spray overtopping on the estuary today, Monday 20/02/2023, between 4:30 PM and 8:00 PM. The areas most at risk is Kilnsea Village. Between these times the combination of high tides and waves is expected to generate hazards for exposed areas. Please be careful along beaches, coastal footpaths and roads as waves and sea spray could be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 20/02/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Hornsea

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message: This Flood Warning has been issued due to the high tide and surge conditions expected between 4:00 PM and 6:30 PM on Monday 20/02/2023. Areas most at risk include properties in the vicinity of North Promenade and New Road, and in the vicinity of the leisure centre. We will continue to monitor the forecast and will re-issue this warning if necessary over the coming days. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one, remain safe and be aware of your surroundings. This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 20/02/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: This flood alert has been issued due to high tides and forecasted weather conditions which may cause waves and spray overtopping on the coast today, Monday 20/02/2023, between 4:30 PM and 8:00 PM. Areas most at risk include low lying coastal frontages, in particular around Spurn Road and Southfield Farm coastal side. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 20/02/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 11:15 AM on Monday 20/02/2023.
Flooding is possible to low lying land and roads near the coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale between 09:15 AM and 1:15 PM on 20/02/2023.
The following high tide, on Monday night, is not expected to reach alert level, but from Tuesday lunchtime we expect to have a series of high tides which will reach the alert level.
Our incident response staff will be closing flood gates and checking defences.
Plan driving routes to avoid coastal roads, which may be flooded.
This message will be removed or updated by 05:30PM on 20/02/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds.  The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides for the next tide. Spring tides are peaking on Wednesday 22 February and we may issue further alerts for this area. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely and issue any further warnings or alerts as necessary.

items.description: Tweed estuary
items.message: The flood alert has now been removed. There is no longer a risk of flooding in the area. Please continue to take care along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message: This flood alert has been issued due to high tides which may cause  some localise flooding on the coast today, Monday 20/02/2023, between 3:00 PM and 5:00 PM. The area of concern is expected to be New Quay Road at Whitby. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9:00PM, 20/02/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Hessle Haven to Faxfleet
items.message: This flood alert has been issued due to high tides and forecast weather conditions which may cause waves and spray overtopping on the estuary today, Monday 20/02/2023, between 5:30 PM and 8:30 PM. Flooding is possible from the Humber estuary from Hessle Haven to Faxfleet. We will continue to liaise with local authorities and keep closely monitoring the situation. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, which may be flooded. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9:00 PM on 20/02/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 17:30 and 19:30 today, Monday 20th February. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. We expect to see water on roads and footpaths to beaches and on the quays in Brancaster, Burnham Overy, Holkham, Wells and Blakeney.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.72 mAODN at 18:30 today which is 0.63m above tide tables, wind Force 5, South Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Spring tides are peaking Wednesday 22nd February, and high-water levels may be seen during this time. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Tuesday 21st February.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message: This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 08:00 AM on 21/02/2023. Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton. The next high tide is expected to be higher than normal and may result in us issuing a further alert. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. Plan driving routes to coastal roads, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 21/02/2023, or as the situation changes.

Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. We may see water on Beach Road at Cley, Beach Road at Salthouse, and footpaths in the marshes may also become inaccessible. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.72 mAODN at 18:30 today which is 0.63m above tide tables, wind Force 5, South Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Spring tides are peaking on Wednesday 22nd February, and high-water levels may be seen during this time. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10:00 tomorrow, Tuesday 21st February.

items.description: The Suffolk coast at Southwold
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 20:15 and 22:15 today, Monday 20th February. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. We expect high tide levels at the harbourside in Southwold. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 1.69 mAODN at 21:15 today which is 0.6m above tide tables, wind Force 4, South Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Spring tides are peaking on Wednesday 22nd February, high water levels may be seen during this time. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Tuesday 21st February.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tides from Tuesday morning (21st February) until Thursday morning (23rd). High water Tuesday morning in Ilfracombe is at 06:45, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Up to force 3 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 1.1m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations on Tuesday morning. Expect tides to be around 10cm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates Tuesday afternoon. 
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe is 5.21 mAOD, this is 0.9 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: North Cornwall coast from Lands End to Chapel Porth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the morning high tides on Tuesday 21st and Wednesday 22nd February. High water at St Ives is at 05:51am on Tuesday and 06:35am on Wednesday, times of high water will vary along the coast. 

Winds of up to force 5 from the South veering to Northwest and offshore wave heights of up to 2 metres are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations including St Ives Harbour, Portreath Harbour and the Causeway at Hayle. 

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. 

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required. 

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe on Tuesday morning is 5.21 mAOD, this is 0.09 metres above astronomical tide level, and on Wednesday morning is 5.30 mAOD, this is 0.05 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Lizard Point to Gribbin Head excluding Truro City
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on the morning of Wednesday 22nd February. High water at Truro is at 06:52am, times of high water will vary along the coast. 

Winds of up to Force 6 from the Northwest with wave heights over 2 metres are forecast. Locations particularly at risk include low lying areas along the tidal rivers Helford and Fal, including the A39 at Perranarworthal, and exposed coastal locations including Portmellon seafront, Mevagissey Harbour area, and Portholland.  Expect tides to be around 100mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions. 

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. 

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required. 

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Newlyn is 3.05 mAOD, this is 0.09 metres above astronomical tide level.

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. 

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.

items.description: North Cornwall coast from The Rumps to Hartland Point excluding Bude
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Tuesday and Wednesday morning. High water at Padstow is at 06:00 AM on Tuesday 21st February and at 06:42 AM on Wednesday 22nd February, times of high water will vary along the coast.

Strong force 5 winds from the south, veering to the north-west, and wave heights of up to 2m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Padstow on Tuesday morning is 4.20 mAOD, this is 0.03 metres below astronomical tide level, and on Wednesday morning is 4.27 mAOD, this is 0.07 metres below astronomical tide level.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message:
A tidal surge is expected to affect the foreshore as a result of high spring tides and strong winds.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible at high tide tomorrow morning, Tuesday 21/02/23, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow.
No tidal peaks above flood alert threshold are expected during this evenings tides, Monday 20/02/23.
Predicted peaks for Tuesday 21/02/23. Avonmouth Portbury 7.5m to 7.8m at 08:00 on 21/02/23, Newport 7.1m to 7.3m at 08:00 on 21/02/23. A series of high tides is due over the next 4 days. We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 21/02/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Ramsgate to Kingsdown
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This Flood Alert has been issued due to a high tide forecast tonight, Monday 20/02/2023. High water levels are expected to affect the foreshore from Ramsgate to Kingsdown. Tides will be at their highest between 21:30 and 01:30, with high tide expected at 23:30. Flooding to roads and low lying land is expected at these times, however these conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. We expect flooding to affect coastal areas, particularly low lying land and roads nearest the sea. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. We are closely monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21/02/2023, or as the situation changes. For those that use it, the astronomical level will be 3.18m AOD and a total water level 3.63m AOD.

items.description: Coast from St Margaret's at Cliffe to Sandgate
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This Flood Alert has been issued due to a high tide forecast tonight, Monday 20/02/2023. High water levels are expected to affect the foreshore from St Margarets at Cliffe to Sandgate. Tides will be at their highest between 21:30 and 01:30, with high tide expected at 23:30. Flooding to roads and low lying land is expected at these times, however these conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. We expect flooding to affect coastal areas, particularly low lying land and roads nearest the sea. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. We are closely monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21/02/2023, or as the situation changes. For those that use it, the astronomical level will be 3.18m AOD and the total water level will be 3.63m AOD.
